test_cases: : COMPREHENSIVE TEST CASES #### TC_001 **Test Title:** Navigate to Profiler Troubleshooting page from Profiler Configuration menu **Category:** positive **Priority:** High **Description:** Validate that an authenticated admin user can successfully navigate to the Profiler Troubleshooting page via the Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Troubleshooting menu path and see correct breadcrumb and basic controls. **Prerequisites:** - Pulse Policy Secure (PPS) with Profiler licensed and enabled. - Admin user `TPSAdmin` with full Profiler administration permissions. - Web UI accessible at `https://pps-profiler01.corp.acme.com/admin`. **Test Data:** - Username: `TPSAdmin` - Password: `TPSAdmin!2024` **Test Steps:** 1. Open a browser (latest Chrome) and navigate to `https://pps-profiler01.corp.acme.com/admin`. 2. Log in using `TPSAdmin / TPSAdmin!2024`. 3. In the top navigation, click on **Profiler**. 4. In the Profiler dropdown, hover over **Profiler Configuration**. 5. In the sub-menu, click **Troubleshooting**. **Expected Results:** - User is successfully authenticated and sees the PPS admin UI. - The **Profiler** tab is highlighted. - The Profiler configuration dropdown shows options: *Server Configuration, Advance Management, Forward and Sync Endpoint Data, Troubleshooting*. - After step 5, the main content area shows a title related to **Troubleshooting** (e.g., "Profiler Troubleshooting" or "Troubleshooting") and/or logging/tests sections as per documentation index (Troubleshooting, Tests, Diagnostic Logs, Profiler Logs). - Breadcrumb on the page displays `Profiler Configuration > Troubleshooting`. **Postconditions:** - User remains logged in on the Profiler Troubleshooting page. No configuration data changed. --- #### TC_002 **Test Title:** Verify display of Profiler Troubleshooting sections (Tests, Diagnostic Logs, Profiler Logs) **Category:** positive **Priority:** Critical **Description:** Ensure that the Profiler Troubleshooting page exposes all main sub-sections listed in documentation: Troubleshooting, Tests, Diagnostic Logs, Profiler Logs. **Prerequisites:** - User is logged in as `TPSAdmin` and on Profiler Troubleshooting page (from TC_001). **Test Data:** - N/A **Test Steps:** 1. On the Profiler Troubleshooting page, visually inspect the page layout. 2. Locate section headers/links/tabs labeled (or similarly labeled): *Troubleshooting*, *Tests*, *Diagnostic Logs*, *Profiler Logs*. 3. Click on each section/tab one by one. **Expected Results:** - Page shows four distinct sections or tabs: *Troubleshooting*, *Tests*, *Diagnostic Logs*, *Profiler Logs*, consistent with documentation TOC (Context 10). - Clicking each section loads a corresponding panel or subpage without errors (no HTTP 4xx/5xx, no JS errors in console). - The active section is clearly highlighted when selected. **Postconditions:** - Troubleshooting UI sections accessible and functional; no configuration changes applied. --- #### TC_003 **Test Title:** Enable Profiler Diagnostic Logging from Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring **Category:** positive **Priority:** Critical **Description:** Validate that Profiler Diagnostic Logging can be enabled as described and that the setting persists. **Prerequisites:** - PPS system running. - User `TPSAdmin` logged into admin UI. - Profiler Diagnostic Logging currently OFF. **Test Data:** - Navigation path: `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. **Test Steps:** 1. From top navigation, click **Maintenance**. 2. From Maintenance menu, select **Troubleshooting**. 3. Select **Monitoring** (if sub-tab). 4. Click on **Diagnostic Logs**. 5. Locate the checkbox or toggle labeled **Profiler Diagnostic Logging On**. 6. Enable the checkbox/toggle. 7. Click **Save Changes** or equivalent button. 8. Refresh the page or navigate away and back to **Diagnostic Logs**. **Expected Results:** - Diagnostic Logs page opens without error. - A control labeled **Profiler Diagnostic Logging On** is visible and initially unchecked/disabled. - After enabling and saving, the setting is stored successfully; no validation errors. - After refresh/navigation back, the **Profiler Diagnostic Logging On** control remains enabled, confirming persistence. **Postconditions:** - Profiler diagnostic logging remains enabled for subsequent operations. --- #### TC_004 **Test Title:** Verify Profiler Diagnostic Log events PRO31748/PRO31749 generated when endpoint information uploaded to Pulse One **Category:** integration **Priority:** High **Description:** Confirm that when endpoints upload information to Pulse One (via Profiler), diagnostic log entries with Event IDs PRO31748 and PRO31749 appear in Profiler Diagnostic Logs. **Prerequisites:** - Profiler Diagnostic Logging enabled (TC_003). - PPS Profiler integrated with Pulse One and capable of forwarding endpoint data. - At least one endpoint actively uploading information to Pulse One (e.g., test endpoint `WIN10-TEST01`). **Test Data:** - Endpoint hostname: `WIN10-TEST01` - Endpoint IP: `10.1.1.100` **Test Steps:** 1. Confirm Profiler is configured to forward/sync endpoint data to Pulse One (Profiler Configuration > Forward and Sync Endpoint Data is configured and enabled). 2. On the endpoint `WIN10-TEST01`, trigger an action that causes the profiler to upload endpoint information (e.g., endpoint connects to network and is profiled, or manual sync initiated). 3. Wait for the configured upload interval plus 2–3 minutes. 4. In PPS UI, navigate to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 5. Filter or search Diagnostic Logs for Event IDs `PRO31748` and `PRO31749` and for IP `10.1.1.100` or hostname `WIN10-TEST01`. **Expected Results:** - Endpoint profiling/upload to Pulse One completes without error. - At least one diagnostic log entry with Event ID `PRO31748` is present, indicating relevant diagnostic message. - At least one diagnostic log entry with Event ID `PRO31749` is present. - Diagnostic log entries contain details about endpoint `WIN10-TEST01` or its IP `10.1.1.100`. - Timestamps are within the timeframe of the triggered upload. **Postconditions:** - Diagnostic log entries remain stored according to system log retention policies. --- #### TC_005 **Test Title:** Verify "Select Events to Log" options for Profiler-related events **Category:** positive **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Confirm that the "Select Events to Log" panel lists relevant Profiler events (poller events, system errors, enforcer command trace, Pulse One events) and allows multiple selections. **Prerequisites:** - Admin logged in as `TPSAdmin`. - Profiler enabled. **Test Data:** - Events to verify: Poller events logging, System errors logging, Enforcer command trace, Pulse One events logging (from Context 2). **Test Steps:** 1. Navigate to the logging configuration section (likely under `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs` or a Logs > Settings page). 2. Locate the **Select Events to Log** header. 3. Inspect the list of checkboxes under this header. 4. Verify presence of checkboxes for: - Poller events logging - System errors logging - Enforcer command trace - Pulse One events logging 5. Select all four checkboxes. 6. Click **Save Changes**. 7. Re-open the same configuration page. **Expected Results:** - "Select Events to Log" section is visible. - All four event categories are available as independent checkboxes. - Multiple checkboxes can be checked simultaneously. - After saving and reopening, the selected checkboxes remain checked, confirming persistence. **Postconditions:** - Logging configuration updated to log all selected events. --- #### TC_006 **Test Title:** Reset Profiler basic configuration and verify Troubleshooting still accessible **Category:** integration **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Validate that resetting basic Profiler configuration does not break access to Profiler Troubleshooting page. **Prerequisites:** - Profiler basic configuration previously saved. - User `TPSAdmin` logged in. **Test Data:** - Profiler menu path: `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Server Configuration` (or Basic config page referenced in Contexts 3 and 4). **Test Steps:** 1. Navigate to `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Server Configuration` (basic configuration page). 2. Click **Reset** to revert to default settings. 3. Confirm reset action if a confirmation dialog appears. 4. After reset completes, navigate to `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Troubleshooting`. **Expected Results:** - Basic configuration reset is successful; page returns to default values, no errors. - Profiler feature remains enabled (license not removed). - Navigating to Troubleshooting still works; the Troubleshooting page loads with all sections as per TC_002. - No license/module errors such as "Module not in use" displayed for Profiler. **Postconditions:** - Profiler basic config in default state; Troubleshooting still functional. --- #### TC_007 **Test Title:** Attempt to access Profiler Troubleshooting without sufficient privileges **Category:** negative **Priority:** High **Description:** Verify that users without admin/Profiler permissions cannot access Profiler Troubleshooting or modify diagnostic logging. **Prerequisites:** - Create a limited user `PulseUser` with read-only or no Profiler administration rights. - Profiler enabled on PPS. **Test Data:** - Username: `PulseUser` - Password: `PulseUser!2024` **Test Steps:** 1. Log out any existing session. 2. Log into PPS admin UI as `PulseUser`. 3. Check if the **Profiler** menu is visible. 4. If visible, attempt to open `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Troubleshooting`. 5. Attempt to navigate to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 6. Try to enable/disable **Profiler Diagnostic Logging On** and save. **Expected Results:** - Depending on role: - Profiler menu may not be visible at all, OR - Profiler Troubleshooting access is restricted (e.g., greyed out, access denied message, or redirect). - If user reaches Diagnostic Logs page: - Controls like **Profiler Diagnostic Logging On** are read-only or hidden. - Save actions are blocked with an authorization error message (e.g., "You do not have permission to perform this action"). - No configuration changes are applied as a result of this user’s actions. **Postconditions:** - Profiler diagnostic logging configuration remains unchanged. --- #### TC_008 **Test Title:** Verify behavior when enabling Profiler Diagnostic Logging with invalid/expired license **Category:** negative **Priority:** High **Description:** Ensure that if Profiler license is missing/expired, enabling Profiler Diagnostic Logging fails gracefully with clear error messaging. **Prerequisites:** - PPS instance with Profiler license removed or expired (simulate by deactivating Profiler SKU on license portal). - Admin `TPSAdmin` logged in. **Test Data:** - Profiler license SKU: e.g., `PS-PROFILER-LG-SKU` (should be inactive). **Test Steps:** 1. Confirm in License Management that Profiler module shows "Module not in use" or similar message in footer (Context 3). 2. Navigate to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 3. Locate the **Profiler Diagnostic Logging On** control. 4. Attempt to enable it and save changes. **Expected Results:** - If Profiler module is not licensed: - Either the Profiler-related logging option is disabled/hidden, or - On enable attempt, user receives a clear error message (e.g., "Profiler module not licensed. Profiler Diagnostic Logging cannot be enabled."). - No change is made to logging behavior for Profiler. - Footer or license area continues to show "Module not in use" for Profiler. **Postconditions:** - Profiler diagnostic logging remains disabled; license state unchanged. --- #### TC_009 **Test Title:** Validate system behavior when Profiler Diagnostic Logging storage is full **Category:** negative **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Confirm how the system handles log generation when diagnostic log storage reaches capacity (e.g., rotation, error messages). **Prerequisites:** - Profiler Diagnostic Logging enabled. - Log storage quota known (e.g., 1 GB for diagnostic logs). - Ability to simulate or reach near-full log storage (e.g., via log-generation script or extended logging). **Test Data:** - N/A (environmental test). **Test Steps:** 1. Generate Profiler activity (profiling devices, syncing to Pulse One, etc.) to quickly produce diagnostic logs. 2. Monitor syslogs or system storage until diagnostic log partition approaches full capacity (e.g., 95–100%). 3. Continue generating activity for additional log events. 4. Open `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs` and attempt to view latest logs. **Expected Results:** - When storage is full or threshold exceeded, system: - Either rotates older logs (FIFO), or - Stops logging new diagnostic entries and displays a warning message (e.g., "Diagnostic log storage full; new entries may not be recorded"). - UI remains responsive; no unhandled exceptions. - No corruption of existing log files. **Postconditions:** - Diagnostic log behavior consistent with configured retention; storage may remain high until cleared. --- #### TC_010 **Test Title:** Boundary test – minimum polling interval for Device Attribute Server and impact on Troubleshooting logs **Category:** boundary **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Verify that setting the minimum allowed polling interval for Device Attribute Server is accepted and events appear properly in diagnostic logs. **Prerequisites:** - Device Attribute Server already configured as HTTP Attribute Server under Profiler. - Admin `TPSAdmin` logged in. **Test Data:** - Polling interval min boundary: assume allowed range 1–1440 minutes (default 720). Test with `1` minute. - Device Attribute Server IP: `10.1.1.101`. **Test Steps:** 1. Navigate to `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Advance` (Advanced Profiler Configuration). 2. Locate **Device Attribute Server settings**. 3. Set **Polling interval** to `1` minute (minimum boundary). 4. Save changes. 5. Ensure Profiler Diagnostic Logging is ON. 6. Wait at least 3–5 minutes. 7. Go to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 8. Filter logs by Device Attribute Server IP `10.1.1.101` or related poller events. **Expected Results:** - System accepts `1` minute as valid polling interval (if documented min is 1). - No validation error for the value. - Diagnostic logs show Poller events corresponding to Device Attribute Server queries approximately every minute. - Logs remain readable and system performance remains acceptable. **Postconditions:** - Polling interval remains at 1 minute until changed; additional logs accumulate more frequently. --- #### TC_011 **Test Title:** Boundary test – maximum polling interval for Device Attribute Server **Category:** boundary **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Confirm that setting the maximum allowed polling interval for the Device Attribute Server is accepted and retained. **Prerequisites:** - Same as TC_010. **Test Data:** - Polling interval max boundary: assume 1440 minutes (24 hours). **Test Steps:** 1. Navigate to Device Attribute Server configuration (Advanced Profiler Configuration). 2. Set **Polling interval** to `1440` minutes. 3. Click **Save Changes**. 4. Re-open the Advanced Profiler Configuration page. **Expected Results:** - System accepts `1440` as a valid value (if within documented constraints). - No error messages on saving. - Polling interval value remains `1440` when reloading the page. **Postconditions:** - Polling interval set to 24 hours; poller activity reduced accordingly. --- #### TC_012 **Test Title:** Boundary/negative – invalid polling interval (zero, negative, non-numeric) **Category:** boundary **Priority:** High **Description:** Ensure robust validation for polling interval input by rejecting 0, negative numbers, and non-numeric values. **Prerequisites:** - Admin `TPSAdmin` logged in. **Test Data:** - Invalid values: `0`, `-5`, `9999999`, `abc`, `1.5`. **Test Steps:** 1. Navigate to Advanced Profiler Configuration > Device Attribute Server settings. 2. In the **Polling interval** field, enter `0`. 3. Click **Save Changes**. 4. Observe validation response. 5. Repeat steps 2–4 for values `-5`, `9999999`, `abc`, `1.5`. **Expected Results:** - For `0` and `-5`: - System displays inline validation error (e.g., "Polling interval must be a positive integer within allowed range"). - Value is not saved. - For extremely large `9999999`: - Value rejected with range validation error, or automatically constrained to max allowed value with warning. - For `abc` and `1.5`: - Input rejected as invalid type; user receives error message, and field is not updated. - No server-side errors or crashes; form remains usable. **Postconditions:** - Polling interval remains unchanged from last valid value. --- #### TC_013 **Test Title:** Verify Profiler Troubleshooting page and logs over HTTPS only (no plain HTTP) **Category:** security **Priority:** High **Description:** Ensure that access to Profiler Troubleshooting and Diagnostic Logs is only allowed over HTTPS, and HTTP access is redirected or blocked. **Prerequisites:** - PPS configured to use HTTPS for admin. - HTTP port either disabled or configured to redirect to HTTPS. **Test Data:** - HTTPS URL: `https://pps-profiler01.corp.acme.com/admin`. - HTTP URL: `http://pps-profiler01.corp.acme.com/admin`. **Test Steps:** 1. In browser, request `http://pps-profiler01.corp.acme.com/admin`. 2. Observe response (redirect or error). 3. Then request `https://pps-profiler01.corp.acme.com/admin` and log in as `TPSAdmin`. 4. Navigate to `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Troubleshooting`. 5. Navigate to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 6. Open browser developer tools and verify protocol/security for these pages. **Expected Results:** - HTTP request is either: - Redirected (301/302) to HTTPS, or - Blocked with a security message indicating HTTPS required. - Admin and Troubleshooting pages are served over HTTPS only. - No mixed-content warnings in browser when viewing Troubleshooting or Diagnostic Logs (all resources loaded via HTTPS). **Postconditions:** - No unsecured session created; admin session remains over HTTPS. --- #### TC_014 **Test Title:** Security – verify that log search/filter inputs are sanitized against XSS/HTML injection **Category:** security **Priority:** High **Description:** Confirm that search/filter fields on Diagnostic Logs or Profiler Logs do not allow XSS or HTML/JS injection. **Prerequisites:** - Diagnostic or Profiler Logs page with search/filter functionality. - Profiler Diagnostic Logging enabled and logs present. **Test Data:** - Malicious input: `` - HTML input: `test` - SQL-like input: `" OR "1"="1` **Test Steps:** 1. Navigate to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 2. Locate a search/filter field (e.g., search by Event ID, message text). 3. Enter `` in the search field and submit. 4. Observe page behavior and source/DOM after searching. 5. Repeat steps 3–4 with `test` and `" OR "1"="1`. **Expected Results:** - Search executes or returns no results, but input is treated as plain text. - No script execution occurs; no alert dialog appears. - Page layout remains intact; malicious characters are encoded in DOM (e.g., `<` converted to `<`). - No SQL error messages appear in UI or logs. **Postconditions:** - No persistent or reflected XSS vulnerabilities introduced via log search field. --- #### TC_015 **Test Title:** Performance – measure load time of Diagnostic Logs page with high volume of Profiler entries **Category:** performance **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Validate that Diagnostic Logs page remains performant (acceptable response time) even with large numbers of Profiler diagnostic log entries. **Prerequisites:** - Profiler Diagnostic Logging enabled and running for at least 24 hours in a busy environment, generating >100,000 log entries. - Monitoring tool or stopwatch for measuring page load time. **Test Data:** - N/A (performance based). **Test Steps:** 1. Ensure background load has generated large diagnostic log volume. 2. On a client workstation (`Windows 10`, Chrome latest), clear browser cache. 3. Navigate to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 4. Use stopwatch to measure time from clicking navigation link to full page render (including log table). 5. Scroll through the first page of results and perform one search/filter by Event ID (e.g., `PRO31748`). 6. Measure response time for applying filter. **Expected Results:** - Diagnostic Logs page loads within defined performance SLA (e.g., ≤ 5 seconds for initial load under heavy log volume). - Search/filter operation completes within SLA (e.g., ≤ 3 seconds). - UI remains responsive; no timeouts or browser "unresponsive page" warnings. **Postconditions:** - Logs remain intact; no performance degradation beyond measured behavior. --- #### TC_016 **Test Title:** Performance – concurrent admin access to Profiler Troubleshooting and Logs **Category:** performance **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Assess system performance when multiple admins concurrently access Profiler Troubleshooting and Diagnostic Logs. **Prerequisites:** - At least 10 admin accounts (e.g., `Admin01`–`Admin10`). - Load test tool or scripted browsers to simulate concurrent logins. **Test Data:** - Users: `Admin01/Admin01!2024` … `Admin10/Admin10!2024`. **Test Steps:** 1. Using a load tool or parallel sessions, have 10 admin users log in nearly simultaneously to PPS. 2. Each user navigates to `Maintenance > Troubleshooting > Monitoring > Diagnostic Logs`. 3. Each user performs random search/filter operations (Event ID, date range) for 5 minutes. 4. Monitor server CPU, memory, and application response times. **Expected Results:** - System handles 10 concurrent admin sessions without significant degradation. - Each user’s page loads and filter actions complete within acceptable response times (similar to TC_015). - No HTTP 5xx errors or unhandled exceptions occur. - Server resource usage stays within safe thresholds (e.g., CPU < 80%, memory not exhausted). **Postconditions:** - System returns to normal resource usage after test; no lingering instability. --- #### TC_017 **Test Title:** Integration – verify Profiler logs include SNMP/CDP/LLDP poller events **Category:** integration **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Confirm that Profiler logs (not just Diagnostic Logs) record poller events related to SNMP, CDP, and LLDP as per Profiler configuration flow. **Prerequisites:** - Profiler configured with SNMP collectors for network switches and CDP/LLDP enabled (per Context 7 and 9). - Profiler polling active. - Profiler Logs section available under Troubleshooting. **Test Data:** - Switch IP: `10.1.1.150`. - SNMP community: `public-profiler`. **Test Steps:** 1. Ensure network switches are configured to support SNMP, CDP, LLDP and are reachable from Profiler. 2. Navigate to `Profiler > Profiler Configuration > Advance` and confirm SNMP Devices configured. 3. Wait for at least one polling cycle (per configured intervals). 4. Navigate to Profiler Logs section (`Profiler Troubleshooting > Profiler Logs`). 5. Filter logs by device IP `10.1.1.150` or by event type "SNMP" / "CDP" / "LLDP". **Expected Results:** - Profiler logs contain entries for poller events related to SNMP, CDP, and/or LLDP. - Each log entry includes at minimum timestamp, device IP, event type, and status (success/failure). - No repeated error patterns indicating misconfiguration unless intentionally present. **Postconditions:** - Profiler logging continues normally; poller events recorded according to settings. --- #### TC_018 **Test Title:** Negative – simulate unreachable Device Attribute Server and verify error logging **Category:** negative **Priority:** High **Description:** Validate that when the Device Attribute Server is unreachable, Profiler records appropriate error entries in Diagnostic/Profiler logs and does not crash. **Prerequisites:** - Device Attribute Server configured with IP `10.1.1.101`. - Profiler Diagnostic Logging ON. **Test Data:** - Device Attribute Server IP: `10.1.1.101` (simulate outage by shutting down server or blocking network). **Test Steps:** 1. Confirm normal operation: ensure Device Attribute Server is reachable and a successful poll event appears in Profiler logs. 2. Simulate failure by: - Shutting down device at `10.1.1.101`, or - Adding a firewall rule blocking traffic from PPS to `10.1.1.101`. 3. Wait for at least one polling interval. 4. Navigate to Diagnostic Logs and Profiler Logs pages. 5. Filter for events related to `10.1.1.101` or poller errors. **Expected Results:** - Profiler does not hang or crash when server is unreachable. - Diagnostic/Profiler logs contain clear error messages indicating unreachable Device Attribute Server or timeout. - Error entries are timestamped and correspond to expected polling attempts. - After restoring connectivity and waiting for one more polling interval, subsequent logs show successful polling again. **Postconditions:** - System returns to normal behavior when Device Attribute Server is back online. --- #### TC_019 **Test Title:** Negative – invalid filtering criteria on logs (out-of-range dates, malformed event ID) **Category:** negative **Priority:** Medium **Description:** Verify that invalid filter parameters for Diagnostic/Profiler logs are handled gracefully without breaking the UI. **Prerequisites:** - Logs present in Diagnostic and Profiler Logs pages. **Test Data:** - Date range: start date `01-01-1900`, end date `01-01-1901`. - Malformed Event ID: `PROXXXXX`. **Test Steps:** 1. Open Diagnostic Logs page. 2. Set a date range filter from `01-01-1900` to `01-01-1901` (far outside realistic logs). 3. Apply filter. 4. Observe results. 5. In Event ID filter, enter `PROXXXXX` (invalid format). 6. Apply filter again. **Expected Results:** - For out-of-range date filter: - System either warns about invalid date range or returns "No results found" quickly. - For malformed Event ID filter: - No server error; either "No results found" or client-side validation error. - UI remains stable; no 500 errors or broken layout. **Postconditions:** - Filters can be reset to default with all logs visible again. --- #### TC_020 **Test Title:** Security – verify access control on Troubleshooting/Logs API endpoints **Category:** security **Priority:** Critical **Description:** Confirm that backend API endpoints used by Profiler Troubleshooting and Logs cannot be accessed by unauthenticated or unauthorized users via direct URL/API calls. **Prerequisites:** - Ability to use a tool like Postman/curl. - Knowledge of log-related API endpoints (e.g., `/api/logs/diagnostic`, `/api/profiler/logs` if exposed). **Test Data:** - API URL patterns observed from browser dev tools (network tab). **Test Steps:** 1. In browser as `TPSAdmin`, open Diagnostic Logs and inspect Network tab to identify the REST endpoints (e.g., `GET /api/diagnostic-logs`). 2. Copy one of these URLs. 3. In Postman/curl from a client with no valid session cookie or token, issue a GET request to that URL. 4. Observe HTTP status and response body. 5. Log in as a low-privilege user `PulseUser` (without Troubleshooting permission) and repeat the GET request with that user’s session cookie/token. **Expected Results:** - Unauthenticated request: - Returns HTTP 401/403 with no sensitive data in body. - Low-privilege user request: - Returns HTTP 403 or a safe error indicating insufficient permissions; no log content returned. - Only fully authorized admin (like `TPSAdmin`) can retrieve data via the same endpoints. **Postconditions:** - No unauthorized disclosure of log data via APIs. ---
test_plan:
: TEST PLANNING ANALYSIS

1. **Feature Overview:**  
   - The tests cover the Profiler Troubleshooting capability of Pulse Policy Secure Profiler, including navigation to Troubleshooting UI under Profiler Configuration, related sub-sections (Tests, Diagnostic Logs, Profiler Logs), configuration of Profiler Diagnostic Logging, logging of poller and Pulse One events (PRO31748/PRO31749), Device Attribute Server polling, and associated security, integration, and performance aspects.

2. **Test Objectives:**  
   - Verify correct access and display of Profiler Troubleshooting UI and sub-sections.  
   - Validate that Profiler Diagnostic Logging can be enabled/disabled and persists correctly.  
   - Confirm that expected log events (poller, errors, Pulse One uploads) are generated and viewable.  
   - Ensure robust input validation and error handling (invalid inputs, unreachable servers, full log storage).  
   - Validate integration with Device Attribute Server, Pulse One, SNMP/CDP/LLDP collectors.  
   - Confirm proper access control, transport security (HTTPS), and input sanitization.  
   - Assess performance and scalability of Troubleshooting and Logs under load and concurrency.

3. **Coverage Analysis (20 test cases):**  
   - Positive: TC_001, TC_002, TC_003, TC_005, TC_006, TC_010, TC_011, TC_017 (8 tests)  
   - Negative: TC_007, TC_008, TC_009, TC_012, TC_018, TC_019 (6 tests)  
   - Boundary: TC_010, TC_011, TC_012 (3 tests; note overlap)  
   - Integration: TC_004, TC_006, TC_017, TC_018 (4 tests)  
   - Security: TC_013, TC_014, TC_020 (3 tests)  
   - Performance: TC_015, TC_016 (2 tests)  

   Some tests are cross-cutting (e.g., TC_010/011 appear in positive and boundary), providing multi-dimensional coverage.

4. **Risk Areas / High-Priority Focus:**  
   - **Logging Reliability & Data Integrity:** Ensuring diagnostic and profiler logs (especially PRO31748/PRO31749 and poller events) are consistently generated and preserved under failure and load (TC_004, TC_009, TC_017, TC_018).  
   - **Configuration & Validation:** Polling interval and diagnostic logging configuration must be robustly validated to prevent misconfigurations that can harm performance or visibility (TC_003, TC_010–TC_012).  
   - **Security & Access Control:** Unauthorized access to troubleshooting/log data and XSS/injection risks in filter/search fields (TC_007, TC_013, TC_014, TC_020).  
   - **Performance at Scale:** Diagnostic/Profiler logs can grow quickly; UI and backend must handle high volumes and concurrency without impacting production systems (TC_015, TC_016, TC_009).  

Additional tests can be derived for: role-based access granularity, log export/import, time-zone handling in logs, and detailed "Tests" subsection behavior when more documentation is available.
